description: A manuscript copy of a manuscript original. Shows area on the north side of Staten Island adjoining Kill Van Kull. Pen-and-ink on tracing linen, mounted on cloth. Oriented with norh toward the lower left. Includes notes. In pen and ink on octagonal blue bordered label in lower right corner: 851 n 53 1823. Transferred from the USCGS January 15, 1914. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.

contributors: U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey, previous owner.

description: This record covers single maps of Alaska covering various subjects, which are not represented in the LC database by separate catalog records. This collection includes single printed maps and photocopies of printed or manuscript single maps and may also include some multi-sheet single maps, plates from atlases, books or periodicals, and printed facsimiles. These maps show various subjects, including mines and mineral resources, oil and gas, and population. To request a specific map or for more information, contact a reference librarian in the Geography & Map Division (202) 707-6277 or through the "Ask a librarian" link through the Geography & Map Division website https://www.loc.gov/rr/geogmap/. Title supplied by cataloger. Drawer 20 includes index maps to completed and prospective mapping by the U.S. Geological Survey. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. Drawers 20-26

description: This record covers single maps of Hawaii cities and towns, which are not represented in the LC database by separate catalog records. Uncataloged maps of Honolulu are covered by a separate collection level record. This collection includes single printed maps and blueline prints and may include photocopies of printed or manuscript single maps as well as some multi-sheet single maps, plates from atlases, books or periodicals, and printed facsimiles. These maps may also show various subjects, such as land owners and recreation and tourism. To request a specific map or for more information, contact a reference librarian in the Geography & Map Division (202) 707-6277 or through the "Ask a librarian" link through the Geography & Map Division website https://www.loc.gov/rr/geogmap/. Title supplied by cataloger. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. Drawers 18, 22-25.

medium: 5 drawers of maps : some color, some hand colored, some photocopies ; various sizes.

These maps may also show various subjects, such as land owners and recreation and tourism. To request a specific map or for more information, contact a reference librarian in the Geography & Map Division (202) 707-6277 or through the "Ask a librarian" link through the Geography & Map Division website https://www.loc.gov/rr/geogmap/.

description: The collection consists of 477 maps from World War I created by American and French forces that show trenches and related military information in France and Belgium.

medium: 477 maps : some color ; 100 x 100 cm or smaller.
notes: Relief shown by contours and spot heights.
Title supplied by cataloger.
In upper left or right margin of some sheets: Groupe des canevas de tir; Canevas de tir; Plan directeur.
On verso of 1 sheet: Carte de France à 1/200.000. Aix-la-Chapelle.
Includes various issues of some sheets.
One sheet printed on both sides.
Some sheets include index to adjoining sheets and boundary diagram.
On some sheets: Secret.
Some sheets stamped Summerall Papers.
Some sheets stamped G-2-C, indicating that the U.S. Army printed the map.
Some sheets cover Belgium.
Trenches and other military positions are illustrated in red, blue or both.
An index map is stored with the collection.
Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image.
Finding aid available in the Geography and Map Reading Room and at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/eadgmd.gm019004
LC copy imperfect: Some sheets brittle.
repository: Library of Congress Geography and Map Division Washington, D.C. 20540-4650 USA dcu

description: "504963 (547149) 3-82." Shows ethnolinguistic groups: Altaic, Indo-European, Caucasian, and Hamito-Semitic families. Covers mostly Middle East, eastward, from Syria to Tibet, China/New Delhi, India, and southward, from Aral Sea area, Russia to Arabian Sea. "Proof copy." Includes legend/index to peoples. Available also through the Library of Congress Web site as a raster image. LC copy annotated in pencil on recto: 63. Vault
